column1: Goodnight Moon;Margaret Wise Brown wrote hundreds of books and stories during her life

column1: The Cat in the Hat;"Theodor Seuss Geisel was born 2 March 1904 in Springfield
column2: Massachusetts. He graduated Dartmouth College in 1925
column3: and proceeded on to Oxford University with the intent of acquiring a doctorate in literature. At Oxford he met Helen Palmer
column4: who he wed in 1927. He returned from Europe in 1927
column5: and began working for a magazine called Judge
column6: the leading humor magazine in America at the time
column7: submitting both cartoons and humorous articles for them. Additionally
column8: he was submitting cartoons to Life
column9: Vanity Fair and Liberty. In some of his works
column10: he'd made reference to an insecticide called Flit. These references gained notice
column11: and led to a contract to draw comic ads for Flit. This association lasted 17 years
column12: gained him national exposure
column13: and coined the catchphrase ""Quick
column14: Henry
column15: the Flit!"" In 1936 on the way to a vacation in Europe
column16: listening to the rhythm of the ship's engines
column17: he came up with And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street
column18: which was then promptly rejected by the first 43 publishers he showed it to. Eventually in 1937 a friend published the book for him
column19: and it went on to at least moderate success. During World War II
column20: Geisel joined the army and was sent to Hollywood. Captain Geisel would write for Frank Capra's Signal Corps Unit (for which he won the Legion of Merit) and do documentaries (he won Oscar's for Hitler Lives and Design for Death). He also created a cartoon called Gerald McBoing-Boing which also won him an Oscar. In May of 1954
column21: Life published a report concerning illiteracy among school children. The report said
column22: among other things
column23: that children were having trouble to read because their books were boring. This inspired Geisel's publisher
column24: and prompted him to send Geisel a list of 400 words he felt were important
column25: asked him to cut the list to 250 words (the publishers idea of how many words at one time a first grader could absorb)
column26: and write a book. Nine months later
column28: using 220 of the words given to him published

column1: The Cat in the Hat

column2: which went on to instant success. In 1960 Bennett Cerf bet Geisel $50 that he couldn't write an entire book using only fifty words. The result was

column1: Green Eggs and Ham

. Cerf never paid the $50 from the bet. Helen Palmer Geisel died in 1967. Theodor Geisel married Audrey Stone Diamond in 1968. Theodor Seuss Geisel died 24 September 1991. Also worked under the pen name:
Theo Le Sieg

column1: Brideshead Revisited: The Sacred and Profane Memories of Captain Charles Ryder;"Evelyn Waugh's father Arthur was a noted editor and publisher. His only sibling Alec also became a writer of note. In fact
column2: his book “The Loom of Youth” (1917) a novel about his old boarding school Sherborne caused Evelyn to be expelled from there and placed at Lancing College. He said of his time there

column4: really.” He went on to Hertford College

column6: where he read History. When asked if he took up any sports there he quipped
column7: “I drank for Hertford.” In 1924 Waugh left Oxford without taking his degree. After inglorious stints as a school teacher (he was dismissed for trying to seduce a school matron and/or inebriation)
column8: an apprentice cabinet maker and journalist
column9: he wrote and had published his first novel
column10: “Decline and Fall” in 1928. In 1928 he married Evelyn Gardiner. She proved unfaithful
column11: and the marriage ended in divorce in 1930. Waugh would derive parts of “A Handful of Dust” from this unhappy time. His second marriage to Audrey Herbert lasted the rest of his life and begat seven children. It was during this time that he converted to Catholicism. During the thirties Waugh produced one gem after another. From this decade come: “Vile Bodies” (1930)
column12: “Black Mischief” (1932)
column13: the incomparable “A Handful of Dust” (1934) and “Scoop” (1938). After the Second World War he published what is for many his masterpiece

column17: “Unconditional Surrender"" (1961) - his career was seen to be on the wane. In fact
column18: “Basil Seal Rides Again” (1963) - his last published novel - received little critical or commercial attention. Evelyn Waugh
column19: considered by many to be the greatest satirical novelist of his day

column21: Brideshead Revisited looks back to the golden age before the Second World War. It tells the story of Charles Ryder's infatuation with the Marchmains and the rapidly-disappearing world of privilege they inhabit. Enchanted first by Sebastian at Oxford

The Chronicles of Narnia;Librarian Note: There is more than one author in the Goodreads database with this name.Clive Staples Lewis was one of the intellectual giants of the twentieth century and arguably one of the most influential writers of his day. He was a Fellow and Tutor in English Literature at Oxford University until 1954. He was unanimously elected to the Chair of Medieval and Renaissance Literature at Cambridge University, a position he held until his retirement. He wrote more than thirty books, allowing him to reach a vast audience, and his works continue to attract thousands of new readers every year. His most distinguished and popular accomplishments include Mere Christianity, Out of the Silent Planet, The Great Divorce, The Screwtape Letters, and the universally acknowledged classics The Chronicles of Narnia. To date, the Narnia books have sold over 100 million copies and been transformed into three major motion pictures.Lewis was married to poet Joy Davidman. W.H. Lewis was his elder brother];628708;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/11127.The_Chronicles_of_Narnia;1956-01-01;0066238501;Librarian note: An alternate cover for this edition can be found here: 2005.Journeys to the end of the world, fantastic creatures, and epic battles between good and evil—what more could any reader ask for in one book? The book that has it all is The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, written in 1949 by Clive Staples Lewis. But Lewis did not stop there. Six more books followed, and together they became known as The Chronicles of Narnia.For the past fifty years, The Chronicles of Narnia have transcended the fantasy genre to become part of the canon of classic literature. Each of the seven books is a masterpiece, drawing the reader into a land where magic meets reality, and the result is a fictional world whose scope has fascinated generations.This edition presents all seven books—unabridged—in one impressive volume. The books are presented here in chronlogical order, each chapter graced with an illustration by the original artist, Pauline Baynes. Deceptively simple and direct, The Chronicles of Narnia continue to captivate fans with adventures, characters, and truths that speak to readers of all ages, even fifty years after they were first published.;C.S. column1: The Giver;"Taken from Lowry's website:""I’ve always felt that I was fortunate to have been born the middle child of three. My older sister
column2: Helen

column9: moved from there to New York
column10: spent the years of World War II in my mother’s hometown: Carlisle

column12: and from there went to Tokyo when I was eleven. High school was back in New York City
column13: but by the time I went to college (Brown University in Rhode Island)
column14: my family was living in Washington
column15: D.C.I married young. I had just turned nineteen - just finished my sophomore year in college - when I married a Naval officer and continued the odyssey that military life requires. California. Connecticut (a daughter born there). Florida (a son). South Carolina. Finally Cambridge
column16: Massachusetts
column17: when my husband left the service and entered Harvard Law School (another daughter; another son) and then to Maine - by now with four children under the age of five in tow. My children grew up in Maine. So did I. I returned to college at the University of Southern Maine
column18: got my degree
column20: and finally began to write professionally
column21: the thing I had dreamed of doing since those childhood years when I had endlessly scribbled stories and poems in notebooks.After my marriage ended in 1977

column23: I settled into the life I have lived ever since. Today I am back in Cambridge
column25: living and writing in a house dominated by a very shaggy Tibetan Terrier named Bandit. For a change of scenery Martin and I spend time in Maine
column26: where we have an old (it was built in 1768!) farmhouse on top of a hill. In Maine I garden
column29: and read...My books have varied in content and style. Yet it seems that all of them deal
column30: essentially
column31: with the same general theme: the importance of human connections. A Summer to Die
column33: was a highly fictionalized retelling of the early death of my sister

column37: and the newest in the trilogy: Messenger - take place against the background of very different cultures and times. Though all three are broader in scope than my earlier books
column38: they nonetheless speak to the same concern: the vital need of people to be aware of their interdependence

column42: with a wish to honor him by joining the many others trying to find a way to end conflict on this very fragile earth.I am a grandmother now. For my own grandchildren - and for all those of their generation - I try
column44: to convey my passionate awareness that we live intertwined on this planet and that our future depends upon our caring more
column46: for one another.""";2345519;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3636.The_Giver;1993-04-26;0385732554;At the age of twelve

column1: The Power of One;"I was born illegitimately in 1933 in South Africa and spent my early childhood years in a small town deep in the heart of the Lebombo mountains.It was a somewhat isolated community and I grew up among farm folk and the African people. At the age of five I was sent to a boarding school which might be better described as a combination orphanage and reform school
column2: where I learned to box - though less as a sport and more as a means to stay alive.But I survived to return to a small mountain town named Barberton in the North Eastern part of the country.Here I met Doc
column3: a drunken German music teacher who spent the next few years filling my young mind with the wonders of nature as we roamed the high mountains. His was the best education I was ever to receive
column4: despite the scholarship I won to a prestigious boy's school and thereafter to a university in England where I studied Journalism.I came to Australia because I was banned from returning to my own country.This was due to the fact that I had started a weekend school for Africans in the school hall of the prestigious boy's school I attended.One day the school hall was raided by the police who then branded me a Communist as they considered educating Africans a subversive act.While studying journalism
column5: I met a wonderful Australian girl.""Come to my country!"" Benita invited.I did
column6: and soon after arriving in Australia
column7: married her. Benita gave me three splendid sons
column8: Brett
column9: Adam and Damon. Brett
column10: who married Ann has given me three lovely grandsons
column11: Ben now 14
column12: Jake is about to turn 12 and Marcus is almost 6 years old.I have lived all my Australian life in Sydney (the nicest place on earth) and
column13: until I started writing fiction
column14: made my career in advertising working as a copywriter and creative director.At the age of 55 I decided to take the plunge. I had been telling stories since the age of five and had always known I would be a writer some day
column15: though life kept getting in the way until I realised that it was either now or never.Bryce Courtenay died at his home in Canberra
column16: Australia. He was 79.Courtenay is survived by his second wife Christine Gee and his children Adam and Brett.";87384;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/122.The_Power_of_One;1989-01-01;034541005X;In 1939

column18: cruel shadow across the world

column21: yet he vows to survive and conceives heroic dreams
column22: which are nothing compared to what life actually has in store for him. He embarks on an epic journey through a land of tribal superstition and modern prejudice where he will learn the power of words

column1: Go Ask Alice;"Beatrice Sparks was an American therapist and Mormon youth counselor who was known for producing books purporting to be the 'real diaries' of troubled teenagers. The books deal with topical issues such as drug abuse
column2: Satanism

column4: and are presented as cautionary tales. Although Sparks always presented herself as merely the discoverer and editor of the diaries

column6: after attending the University of California at Los Angeles and Brigham Young University. She has worked as a music therapist at Utah State Mental Hospital and taught continuing education courses at BYU.Critics have called the precise extent of Sparks' qualifications and experience into question. The editorial credit on some of the diaries published by Sparks identifies her as ""Dr Beatrice Sparks
column7: PhD"". However
column8: when journalist Aileen Pace Nilsen interviewed Sparks for School Library Journal in 1979
column9: she was unable to find any confirmation of where or when Sparks earned her doctorate. Nilsen also wrote that Sparks was ""vague about specifics"" when asked about her counseling qualifications and professional experience.Sparks said that her experience working with troubled adolescents made her want to produce cautionary tales that would keep other teens from falling into the same traps. Her first work

column1: Number the Stars;"Taken from Lowry's website:""I’ve always felt that I was fortunate to have been born the middle child of three. My older sister

column1: Bridge to Terabithia;"From author's website:People are always asking me questions I don't have answers for. One is
column2: ""When did you first know that you wanted to become a writer?"" The fact is that I never wanted to be a writer

column4: or even a young woman. Today I want very much to be a writer. But when I was ten

column6: I wanted to get married and have lots of children.Another question I can't answer is
column7: ""When did you begin writing?"" I can't remember. I know I began reading when I was four or five
column8: because I couldn't stand not being able to. I must have tried writing soon afterward. Fortunately

column10: because the samples that did manage to survive are terrible
column11: with the single exception of a rather nice letter I wrote to my father when I was seven. We were living in Shanghai
column12: and my father was working in our old home territory

column14: and in telling him so

column17: we lived in Virginia and North Carolina
column18: and when our family's return to China was indefinitely postponed

column20: Virginia
column21: and West Virginia
column22: before my parents settled in Winchester
column24: I was ready to begin college. I spent four years at King College in Bristol

Since the church had given me a scholarship to study and I had married instead of going back to work in Japan

column1: The Hiding Place;Corrie ten Boom and her family were Christians who were active in social work in their home town of Haarlem

column7: they were betrayed and Corrie and several relatives were arrested. The four Jews and two underground workers in the house at the time of the arrest were not located by the Nazis and were extricated by the underground 47 hours after they fled to the tiny hiding place (located in Corrie's room). The ten Boom family members were separated and transferred to concentration camps. Corrie was allowed to stay with her precious sister
column8: Betsy. Corrie's father (Casper)
column9: her sister (Betsy) and one grandchild (Kik) perished. Corrie was released in December of 1944.These acts of heroism and sacrifice became the foundation for Corrie ten Boom's global writing and speaking career which began after she was released. column1: Veinte poemas de amor y una canción desesperada;"Pablo Neruda was the pen name and
column2: later
column3: legal name of the Chilean writer and politician Neftalí Ricardo Reyes Basoalto. Neruda assumed his pen name as a teenager
column4: partly because it was in vogue
column5: partly to hide his poetry from his father
column6: a rigid man who wanted his son to have a ""practical"" occupation. Neruda's pen name was derived from Czech writer and poet Jan Neruda; Pablo is thought to be from Paul Verlaine. With his works translated into many languages
column7: Pablo Neruda is considered one of the greatest and most influential poets of the 20th century.Neruda was accomplished in a variety of styles
column8: ranging from erotically charged love poems like his collection Twenty Poems of Love and a Song of Despair
column9: surrealist poems
column10: historical epics
column11: and overtly political manifestos. In 1971 Neruda won the Nobel Prize for Literature
column12: a controversial award because of his political activism. Colombian novelist Gabriel García Márquez once called him ""the greatest poet of the 20th century in any language.""On July 15
column14: at Pacaembu Stadium in São Paulo
column15: Brazil
column16: he read to 100
column17: 000 people in honor of Communist revolutionary leader Luís Carlos Prestes. When Neruda returned to Chile after his Nobel Prize acceptance speech
column18: Salvador Allende invited him to read at the Estadio Nacional before 70
column20: Neruda occupied many diplomatic posts and served a stint as a senator for the Chilean Communist Party. When Conservative Chilean President González Videla outlawed communism in Chile
column21: a warrant was issued for Neruda's arrest. Friends hid him for months in a house basement in the Chilean port of Valparaíso. Later
column22: Neruda escaped into exile through a mountain pass near Maihue Lake into Argentina. Years later
column23: Neruda was a close collaborator to socialist President Salvador Allende.Neruda was hospitalized with cancer at the time of the Chilean coup d'état led by Augusto Pinochet. Three days after being hospitalized
column24: Neruda died of heart failure. Already a legend in life
column25: Neruda's death reverberated around the world. Pinochet had denied permission to transform Neruda's funeral into a public event. However
column26: thousands of grieving Chileans disobeyed the curfew and crowded the streets to pay their respects. Neruda's funeral became the first public protest against the Chilean military dictatorship.";68625;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5932.Twenty_Love_Poems_and_a_Song_of_Despair;1924-01-01;0143039962;When it appeared in 1924
column27: this work launched into the international spotlight a young and unknown poet whose writings would ignite a generation. W. S. Merwin's incomparable translation faces the original Spanish text. Now in a black-spine Classics edition with an introduction by Cristina Garcia
column28: this book stands as an essential collection that continues to inspire lovers and poets around the world.The most popular work by Chile's Nobel Prize-winning poet
column29: and the subject of Pablo Larraín's acclaimed feature film Neruda starring Gael García Bernal.;Pablo Neruda;English;4.23;[];[];5932;Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair

column11: for the United States government
column12: writing radio spots to sell war bonds. He lived a fairly secular lifestyle in his early 20s before deciding to return to a more traditional Jewish way of life
column13: modeled after that of his grandfather
column14: in his mid-20s. Wouk joined the United States Navy and served in the Pacific Theater
column15: an experience he later characterized as educational; ""I learned about machinery

column25: Wouk read each chapter as it was completed to his wife

column30: drawing from his wartime experiences aboard minesweepers during World War II

column36: with whom he had three sons: Abraham
column38: and Joseph. He became a fulltime writer in 1946 to support his growing family. His first-born son

column47: ten days before his 104th birthday.";24514;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/368772.The_Caine_Mutiny;1951-03-19;0316955108;The novel that inspired the now-classic film The Caine Mutiny and the hit Broadway play The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial

column12: she changed into Ayn (after a name of some Finnish author

column20: her first novel and a melodrama
column21: set in Russia. Her first real success was The Fountainhead (rejected by more than ten publishers before publication in 1943).She started a new philosophy

column23: opposed to state interference of all kinds
column24: and her follow-up novel Atlas Shrugged (1957) describes a group who attempt to escape conspiracy of mediocrity of America. Objectivism has been an influence on various other movements such as Libertarianism

column26: and philosophers in general.";151352;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/667.Anthem;1938-05-01;0452281253;"Anthem is Ayn Rand's classic tale of a dystopian future of the great ""We""—a world that deprives individuals of a name or independence—that anticipates her later masterpieces
column27: The Fountainhead and Atlas Shrugged. They existed only to serve the state. They were conceived in controlled Palaces of Mating. They died in the Home of the Useless. From cradle to grave
column28: the crowd was one—the great WE.In all that was left of humanity
column29: there was only one man who dared to think
column30: seek
column31: and love. He lived in the dark ages of the future. In a loveless world
column32: he dared to love the woman of his choice. In an age that had lost all trace of science and civilization
column33: he had the courage to seek and find knowledge. But these were not the crimes for which he would be hunted. He was marked for death because he had committed the unpardonable sin: He had stood forth from the mindless human herd. He was a man alone. He had rediscovered the lost and holy word—I.""I worship individuals for their highest possibilities as individuals

O Pioneers!;Wilella Sibert Cather was born in Back Creek Valley (Gore), Virginia, in December 7, 1873. She grew up in Virginia and Nebraska. She then attended the University of Nebraska, initially planning to become a physician, but after writing an article for the Nebraska State Journal, she became a regular contributor to this journal. Because of this, she changed her major and graduated with a bachelor's degree in English.After graduation in 1894, she worked in Pittsburgh as writer for various publications and as a school teacher for approximately 13 years, thereafter moving to New York City for the remainder of her life. Her novels on frontier life brought her to national recognition. In 1923 she was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for her novel, 'One of Ours' (1922), set during World War I. She travelled widely and often spent summers in New Brunswick, Canada. In later life, she experienced much negative criticism for her conservative politics and became reclusive, burning some of her letters and personal papers, including her last manuscript. She was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1943. In 1944, Cather received the gold medal for fiction from the National Institute of Arts and Letters, an award given once a decade for an author's total accomplishments. She died of a cerebral haemorrhage at the age of 73 in New York City.;52371;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/140963.O_Pioneers_;1913-01-01;0679743626;O Pioneers! (1913) was Willa Cather's first great novel, and to many it remains her unchallenged masterpiece. No other work of fiction so faithfully conveys both the sharp physical realities and the mythic sweep of the transformation of the American frontier—and the transformation of the people who settled it. Cather's heroine is Alexandra Bergson, who arrives on the wind-blasted prairie of Hanover, Nebraska, as a girl and grows up to make it a prosperous farm. But this archetypal success story is darkened by loss, and Alexandra's devotion to the land may come at the cost of love itself.At once a sophisticated pastoral and a prototype for later feminist novels, O Pioneers! is a work in which triumph is inextricably enmeshed with tragedy, a story of people who do not claim a land so much as they submit to it and, in the process, become greater than they were.;Willa Cather;English;3.89;One Book One Nebraska;Evesham Giyt, Alexandra Bergson;140963;O Pioneers!

Not till both children were in junior high did I find time at last to sit down quietly with a pencil and paper. I turned naturally to the things which had filled my days and thoughts and began to write magazine articles about family living. Then one day I stumbled on a true story from New England history with a character who seemed to me an ideal heroine. Her clear, dramatic storytelling covered topics as diverse as the 14th century and World War I, and sold millions of copies.;73844;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40779082-the-guns-of-august;1962-01-01;;Selected by the Modern Library as one of the 100 best nonfiction books of all timeThe Proud Tower, the Pulitzer Prize–winning The Guns of August, and The Zimmerman Telegram comprise Barbara W. Tuchman’s classic histories of the First World War eraIn this landmark, Pulitzer Prize–winning account, renowned historian Barbara W. Tuchman re-creates the first month of World War I: thirty days in the summer of 1914 that determined the course of the conflict, the century, and ultimately our present world. Beginning with the funeral of Edward VII, Tuchman traces each step that led to the inevitable clash. And inevitable it was, with all sides plotting their war for a generation. Dizzyingly comprehensive and spectacularly portrayed with her famous talent for evoking the characters of the war’s key players, Tuchman’s magnum opus is a classic for the ages.;Barbara W. Tuchman;English;4.17;Pulitzer Prize, National Book Award Finalist;[];40779082;The Guns of August

column8: as he felt he was outed as Bachman too early to know. The Bachman book Thinner (1984) sold 28

column26: Stephen King-ish type accident at the age of six

column1: The Power of Myth;"Joseph Campbell was an American author and teacher best known for his work in the field of comparative mythology. He was born in New York City in 1904

column7: the novels of James Joyce and Thomas Mann
column8: and the psychological studies of Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung. These encounters led to Campbell's theory that all myths and epics are linked in the human psyche

column10: cosmological
column11: and spiritual realities. After a period in California
column12: where he encountered John Steinbeck and the biologist Ed Ricketts

column14: and then
column16: joined the literature department at Sarah Lawrence College
column17: a post he retained for many years. During the 40s and '50s

column20: and philosophy. In 1944

column28: and results of the archetypal hero's journey.Throughout his life
column29: he traveled extensively and wrote prolifically
column30: authoring many books
column31: including the four-volume series The Masks of God
column33: The Inner Reaches of Outer Space and The Historical Atlas of World Mythology. Joseph Campbell died in 1987. In 1988
column34: a series of television interviews with Bill Moyers
column36: introduced Campbell's views to millions of people.";50243;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/35519.The_Power_of_Myth;1988-06-01;0385418868;"The Power Of Myth launched an extraordinary resurgence of interest in Joseph Campbell and his work. A preeminent scholar
column38: and teacher
column39: he has had a profound influence on millions of people. To him
column40: mythology was the ""song of the universe
column41: the music of the spheres."" With Bill Moyers
column42: one of America's most prominent journalists

column44: The Power Of Myth touches on subjects from modern marriage to virgin births

column1: The Painted Bird;"Kosiński was born Josef Lewinkopf to Jewish parents in Łódź
column2: Poland. As a child during World War II

column12: and earned degrees in history and political science at the University of Łódź. He worked as an assistant in Institute of History and Sociology at the Polish Academy of Sciences. In 1957

He later fictionalized this marriage in his novel Blind Date speaking of Weir under pseudonym Mary-Jane Kirkland. Kosiński went on to marry Katherina ""Kiki"" von Fraunhofer
column27: a marketing consultant and descendant of Bavarian aristocracy. They met in 1968.DeathKosiński suffered from multiple illnesses towards the end of his life

column1: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions;American historian and philosopher of science
column2: a leading contributor to the change of focus in the philosophy and sociology of science in the 1960s. Thomas Samuel Kuhn was born in Cincinnati
column3: Ohio. He received a doctorate in theoretical physics from Harvard University in 1949. But he later shifted his interest to the history and philosophy of science
column4: which he taught at Harvard
column5: the University of California at Berkeley
column6: Princeton University
column7: and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).In 1962
column8: Kuhn published The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
column9: which depicted the development of the basic natural sciences in an innovative way. According to Kuhn
column10: the sciences do not uniformly progress strictly by scientific method. Rather
column11: there are two fundamentally different phases of scientific development in the sciences. In the first phase
column12: scientists work within a paradigm (set of accepted beliefs). When the foundation of the paradigm weakens and new theories and scientific methods begin to replace it
column13: the next phase of scientific discovery takes place. Kuhn believes that scientific progress—that is
column14: progress from one paradigm to another—has no logical reasoning. Kuhn's theory has triggered widespread
column15: controversial discussion across many scientific disciplines.;26419;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/61539.The_Structure_of_Scientific_Revolutions;1962-01-01;0226458083;A good book may have the power to change the way we see the world
column16: but a great book actually becomes part of our daily consciousness
column17: pervading our thinking to the point that we take it for granted
column18: and we forget how provocative and challenging its ideas once were—and still are. The Structure of Scientific Revolutions is that kind of book. When it was first published in 1962
column19: it was a landmark event in the history and philosophy of science. Fifty years later
column20: it still has many lessons to teach. With The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
column21: Kuhn challenged long-standing linear notions of scientific progress
column22: arguing that transformative ideas don’t arise from the day-to-day
column23: gradual process of experimentation and data accumulation but that the revolutions in science
column24: those breakthrough moments that disrupt accepted thinking and offer unanticipated ideas
column26: ” as he called it. Though Kuhn was writing when physics ruled the sciences
column27: his ideas on how scientific revolutions bring order to the anomalies that amass over time in research experiments are still instructive in our biotech age. This new edition of Kuhn’s essential work in the history of science includes an insightful introduction by Ian Hacking
column28: which clarifies terms popularized by Kuhn
column29: including paradigm and incommensurability
column30: and applies Kuhn’s ideas to the science of today. Usefully keyed to the separate sections of the book
column31: Hacking’s introduction provides important background information as well as a contemporary context.  Newly designed
column33: this edition will be eagerly welcomed by the next generation of readers seeking to understand the history of our perspectives on science.;Thomas S. Kuhn;English;4.03;[];[];61539;The Structure of Scientific Revolutions

column1: Жизнь и судьба;Born Iosif Solomonovich Grossman into an emancipated Jewish family

column5: and eventually murdered together with 20
column7: 000 other Jews who did not evacuate Berdychiv. Grossman was exempt from military service
column8: but volunteered for the front
column9: where he spent more than 1
column10: 000 days. He became a war reporter for the popular Red Army newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda (Red Star). As the war raged on
column11: he covered its major events
column12: including the Battle of Moscow
column13: the Battle of Stalingrad
column14: the Battle of Kursk
column15: and the Battle of Berlin. In addition to war journalism

column17: later renamed For a Just Cause (За правое дело)
